newsitem.title: USA: FORMER MIDDLEWEIGHT BOXING CHAMPION TONY ZALE DIES.
newsitem.headline: FORMER MIDDLEWEIGHT BOXING CHAMPION TONY ZALE DIES.

text.p: Former world middleweight boxing champion Tony Zale, whose three epic bouts against Rocky Graziano in the mid-1940s were considered among the sport's most memorable, has died.
Zale, 83, born Anthony Florian Zaleski, had suffered from cancer and died on Thursday in a nursing home here not far from his birthplace, Gary, Indiana, a family spokesman said.

Nicknamed "The Man of Steel" because he spent time working in Gary's steel mills between bouts, Zale was known as a ferocious body-puncher who won the middleweight crown in 1940. His career halted by a four-year stint in the U.S. Navy during the Seond World War, he returned to the ring to beat Graziano in two of their three fights.

American Sportswriter Red Smith wrote in 1968, "Ask any fight buff of the late 1940s to name the most memorable series fought in his time, and without hesitation he will say the Zale-Graziano battles of 1946, 1947, 1948."
Three months after his last victory over Graziano, Zale lost to Marcel Cerdan and retired at age 35 with a record of 67 wins, 18 losses and two draws.
